G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 1 and related laws governing civil actions for damages.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Worcester County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is expressly recognized under Massachusetts law, codified at G.L. c. 186, § 14, and guarantees that tenants of residential properties shall be free from substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of their leased premises.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes an affirmative duty on landlords to maintain residential rental properties in habitable condition and in compliance with applicable sanitary codes. See G.L. c. 239, § 8A; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes an affirmative duty on landlords to maintain residential rental properties in habitable condition and in compliance with applicable sanitary codes. See G.L. c. 239, § 8A; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: Hemingway is the foundational Massachusetts case recognizing that landlords of residential units have an affirmative, legally enforceable obligation to maintain premises in habitable condition, tied to compliance with statutory and regulatory minimum standards such as the State Sanitary Code. Even in this concurring/dissenting opinion, Justice Quirico expressly states that statutes and codes “impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards,” and that this obligation is implied into the rental relationship. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes an affirmative duty on landlords to maintain habitability and sanitary code compliance, in conjunction with G.L. c. 239, § 8A.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

105 CMR 410.550(A).proposition: A persistent mouse infestation constitutes a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.550(A), which requires that premises be kept free from rodent infestation.

Berman v. Curry, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 84, 8.raw_text: Berman v. Curry, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 84, 88 (2003)
Berman v. Curry, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 84, 8.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to abate a serious defect after receiving notice interferes with a tenant’s legally protected interest in the enjoyment and use of the premises. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Berman v. Curry, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 84, 88 (2003).
Berman v. Curry, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 84, 8.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is from Child v. Child, a Massachusetts divorce/property division case, not Berman v. Curry. It concerns valuation of marital assets, life estates, and trusts in a divorce proceeding and does not address landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of premises. Therefore, this opinion does not support the stated landlord-tenant proposition and appears to be an incorrect or mismatched excerpt for the cited case.
Berman v. Curry, 58 Mass. App. Ct. 84, 8.relevant_excerpt: A probate judge has broad discretion in awarding alimony and making equitable property divisions, but must consider “the length of the marriage, the conduct of the parties during the marriage, the age, health, station, occupation, amount and sources of income, vocational skills, employability, estate, liabilities and needs of each of the parties and the opportunity of each for future acquisition of capital assets and income.” G. L. c. 208, § 34...

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord's failure to maintain the premises in habitable condition, including addressing a rodent infestation, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 720 (1977).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion does address the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it concerns interference from drug activity and the landlord’s failure to take measures against nontenants, not failure to maintain physical conditions like rodent infestations. The court expressly cabins habitability to physical defects and treats quiet enjoyment here as turning on failure to act against third-party criminal activity, without suggesting that general uninhabitability or vermin infestations themselves constitute a quiet enjoyment breach. Thus, the case does not stand for the specific proposition that failure to maintain habitable conditions, including rodent infestations, violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 720.proposition: A landlord's failure to maintain the premises in habitable condition, including addressing a rodent infestation, constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 720 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 720.support_reasoning: Blackett addresses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction where landlords allowed and failed to control extreme noise from a commercial lounge they had introduced near residential units. The case does not discuss habitability standards generally, sanitary conditions, or rodent infestation, and its reference to premises being "reasonably habitable" is in the context of intolerable noise. Thus, while it supports that serious landlord‑created disturbances can breach quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically support the proposition that failure to address a rodent infestation violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 720.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”
